webTitle: The markets this week: from high hopes to default caution

fields.standfirst: As political turmoil continues in the eurozone and solutions fail to materialise, the wait-and-see brigade are setting the pace
fields.body:
In what is starting to become an increasingly regular pattern, the markets spent the first half of the week soaring on high hopes of solid political solutions, only to fall back to its default position of caution when none was forthcoming.

The FTSE had a short week, meaning it had a lot of catching up to do, which it did with aplomb, jumping more than 2% on Wednesday – the biggest one-day rise of the year.

Excitement grew that the Spanish banking crisis could see a resolution, the Bank of England or US Fed would introduce more quantitative easing, and the eurozone interest rates would be cut.

In the end none of the above occurred and the markets had to make do with the wait-and-see brigade maintaining its all too familiar pace, sending the FTSE, French CAC, German DAX and Italian FTSE MIB closing lower.

The FTSE 100 was boosted initially by strong rises from the mining companies, especially after raw material lover China cut its interest rates, spurring hopes for more spending.

But by yesterday realisation dawned that China may be in trouble if it has to cut rates for the first time since 2008, marking Vedanta, down 50p, 5%, to 933.5p, Rio Tinto, down 146p, 4.8%, to £33.39 and Eurasian down 17.4p, 3.9%, to 424.3p, the biggest fallers.

Catalytic converter makers Johnson Matthey provided some much needed cheer to investors, reporting better than expected results and announcing a 100p a share special dividend – the first in its nearly 200-year history. Bosses also increased the final dividend by 20% to 55p, leaving shares closing up 196p on the week at £23.03.

Royal Bank of Scotland's shares closed up 20p on the week at 220p, in its first few days of trading following a stock consolidation. The bank swapped one new share for 10 old ones to make the share price look more at home in the FTSE 100 and avoid the volatility that comes from what was starting to look like a penny share company.

It seems to be working, but the target price for the taxpayer to break even on their 84% investment now looks even further away at 500p instead of 50p at the old price.

Security group G4S held its annual meeting in secret this week amid protests at some of their practices, with some believing the board could be the next for the Shareholder Spring.

In the end the G4S board managed to control its shareholders, suffering the most minor of rebellions.

More troubling times were felt at pan-European publisher Mecom, which announced its second profit warning in as many months, sending shares down nearly 50%, closing at 75.5p. They had been as high as 230p in January.

Non-executive director Michael Hutchinson attempted to reassure the market, buying shares worth nearly £30,000. Unfortunately, none of the executive directors followed suit.

This week saw confirmation that hedge fund operator Man Group will be dumped from the FTSE 100 on 18 June and replaced by engineers Babcock in a reversal of the old adage: "Out with the old, in with the new".

It wasn't all bad news for Man, closing the week at 78.5p, getting an upgrade to "buy" from Citigroup. However, the reasoning from analyst Haley Tam was a back-handed compliment, suggesting "performance cannot get sustainably worse from here".

webTitle: M&S loses further ground in battle for vital womenswear market

fields.standfirst: Retailer's 'middle of the road' fashions and shortages of most popular garments blamed for 0.5% drop in market share
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer has suffered a significant drop in its womenswear market share, which analysts said was a sign that its fashions are too "middle of the road".

The UK's biggest clothing retailer has seen its share drop from 10.9% to 10.4% in the past year as it was hit by tough competition and buying mistakes that saw shortages of bestselling lines.

Investec analyst Bethany Hocking said the decline, revealed in M&S's annual report this week, was larger than expected. M&S's total clothing market share for the year to 15 April was unchanged at 11.7%, buoyed by gains in menswear, lingerie and childrenswear, but Hocking added: "Although the share gain in menswear is a good development, the decline in womenswear is more significant in our view. Women are typically the main household shoppers so womenswear share movements can be leading indicators."

Revealing its annual results last month, M&S chief executive Marc Bolland rowed back on a three-year plan to boost UK group sales by up to £2.5bn, and put the brakes on plans to open more stores, blaming the economic downturn.

"The economy is not allowing us to grow much faster than we are doing today," he said as the company reported a 1% drop in underlying profits to £705.9m for the year to 31 March.

Bolland's pay package dropped from £4.9m in 2011 to £2.5m as his plans to reinvigorate the retailer stalled.

Analysts said the share loss was not down to the stock shortages experienced earlier this year, when M&S admitted it had not bought enough coats and jumpers to get it through the winter, and had failed to stock hot trends such as tribal print fabrics and coloured chinos in sufficient numbers.

Columino analyst Neil Saunders said M&S's women's fashion brands, such as Autograph, Per Una and Indigo, were not distinct enough. "The various brands have converged and become a bit samey, which defeats the object of having them in the first place. It's a bit middle of the road."

M&S's total clothing market share was as high as 14.8% in 1989 but over the past 25 years it has lost ground as rivals such as Next gain momentum. Over that period Next's stake has gone from 1.5% to 7.5%.

Saunders said M&S could not blame the market as upmarket brands such as Hobbs and Whistles had fared well, as had value chains such as Primark, leaving it "caught in the middle" with an ageing shopper base. "M&S's womenswear market share has been in decline for quite a long time," he said. "Other players have put in reasonable performances. M&S has put a foot wrong on womenswear."

While analysts welcomed the retailer's move into banking, they said it was more important for the company to improve the performance of its clothing division, headed by Kate Bostock, which generates more than half of group profits.

M&S Money contributed £50.7m, or 7% of group profits last year. Paul Mumford, portfolio manager at M&S shareholder Cavendish Asset Management, said he doubted the joint venture with HSBC would have much impact on the retailer's profit: "Nevertheless if people get cards and are doing more of their shopping with those, that won't be a bad thing."

Bolland has pushed through a number of personnel changes in the fashion team. Bostock's number two Andrew Skinner, who had been at M&S for 28 years and was responsible for stock management, left earlier this year and was replaced by Bolland's executive assistant Sacha Berendji.

Other initiatives to attract the fashion crowd include a new "fast fashion" collection that promises to deliver the season's key looks with a six-week turnaround.

Staff who plan the clothing ranges are also working more closely with its marketers: adverts featuring models such as Rosie Huntington-Whiteley had caught shoppers' imagination but again M&S's scored an own goal by underestimating demand for the products featured.

Vintage sales

The buildup to the diamond jubilee celebrations resulted in a vintage sales week for department store chain John Lewis.

After a slow start, the retailer said, sales took off with stores posting daily increases of more than 27% by the end. Overall sales finished up 15% in the week to last Saturday.

Despite the rain, fashion sales jumped 20% as optimistic shoppers splashed out on sandals, sunglasses and summer dresses. The chain also reported a run on outdoor furniture as Britons spruced up their gardens ahead of the long weekend of celebrations.

"John Lewis are living on a different planet from the rest of the high street," said retail analyst Nick Bubb. "It is the current pace-setter in the sector."

webTitle: Hornby pins hopes on Moshi Monsters

fields.standfirst: Hornby is hoping new Moshi Monster and London 2012 collectables will make up for a slump in demand for Scalextric and model railways
fields.body:
Hornby is hoping new Moshi Monster and London 2012 collectables will make up for a slump in demand for Scalextric and model railways.

The company, which traces its roots back to 1901 when Frank Hornby received his first patent for Meccano, said it hoped new ranges would help it mitigate the "weakness in our traditional hobby sectors". The unpopularity of model railways, Scalextric and Airfix models has forced Hornby to issue two profits warnings since January and slash its full-year dividend from 5.1p to 3.7p.

Hornby reported a slight drop in full-year pre-tax profits to £4m on sales up 1.7% to £64.4m. It said it hoped the London 2012 Olympics would provide a "spike in sales".

Frank Martin, Hornby's chief executive, said the company had created special products including a fleet of 40 different London taxis decorated in the livery of Olympic sports.

"We've been selling hundreds of thousands of them, and 2012 London buses, and we've had a huge sales of replica Olympic torches," he said.

The London organising committee of the Olympic Games (Locog) reckons sales of London 2012 branded goods will exceed £1bn, with 30% of targeted sales already in the bank. Lesley Low, Locog's retail and licensing manager, said: "We have been experiencing a steady climb in sales since the start of the year, but we don't expect the big lift until the Games itself."

Hornby has recently acquired the rights to Moshi Monsters, the children's online game. It will sell Moshi Monster collectable pin badges and a model of the Moshi bus.

It has also developed a range of toys based on Olly the Little White Van children's TV series.

"Our ability to broaden our product and distribution base will enable us to mitigate to some extent any short-term weakness in our traditional hobby sectors," Martin said.

But he said there would be pressure on consumer confidence for years to come. UK profits for the year to 31 March dropped by more than £1m to £3.4m.

Martin said Scalextric sales were down on last year because of "so much doom and gloom [surrounding] the economies of Europe and austerity measures biting".

Despite the soaring popularity of modern games consoles, Martin said he believed there would continue to be a place for more traditional toys. "In the past when there's a new Wii or Xbox inevitably sales take a bit of a hit, but there an underlying recognition of the social value of [old-fashioned toys]."

Hornby hopes to bring older toys up to date by issuing Star Wars and Olympic velodrome Scalextric models and a string of James Bond merchandise to celebrate the 50th anniversary of Dr No, the first film in the franchise.

Analysts at Numis upgraded their rating on Hornby to "buy" following the results, and said sales of its Olympics-branded products and diversification meant the outlook was "encouraging".

webTitle: GlaxoSmithKline extends tender offer for Human Genome Sciences

fields.bodyText: GlaxoSmithKline's battle to take over its partner Human Genome Sciences is turning increasingly bitter after a poison pill clause forced the British company to extend its $2.6bn (£1.68bn) offer to shareholders of the US biotech firm. GSK, Europe's largest drugmaker, is also looking to appoint its own nominees to the HGS board, which has steadfastly refused its advances. The two companies, which together developed lupus drug Benlysta and have two other medicines in the pipeline, have been locked in the buyout battle for nearly two months. Following its unsolicited offer of $13 a share on 19 April, which was rejected by the HGS management as too low, GSK went directly to HGS shareholders. Its tender offer was due to run out at midnight on Thursday, but the drugmaker extended it until 29 June after receiving only minimal support from HGS investors. Only 474,029 shares were tendered out of a total of around 200m, less than a quarter of a percent of HGS stock. A GSK spokesman said this was not surprising given that HGS invoked a poison pill in mid-May in the hope of derailing the bid. The stockholder rights plan, which will remain in place for a year, enables the Rockville-based firm to dilute any individual or company that acquires more than 15% of the stock. At $13.50, the HGS share price is still above GSK's offer price, suggesting investors are holding out for a higher offer. Despite HGS's hopes for a white knight, a counterbidder has not emerged, but some analysts believe GSK will have to sweeten its offer. "We continue to believe the most likely outcome will be a slightly higher bid from GSK, with no white knights coming to the table with a substantially higher bid," said Ying Huang and Brian Bourdot at Barclays Capital. Mick Cooper, healthcare analyst at Edison Investment Research, agreed. He sees a 50-50 chance that GSK will take over HGS - or walk away, similar to Swiss rival Roche abandoning its $6.7bn hostile bid for Illumina. There could be a long standoff, though - Sanofi-Aventis's $20bn takeover of Genzyme last year took nine months to clinch.

webTitle: FTSE closes down as markets appear unimpressed by Obama's EU pronouncements

fields.standfirst: UK, France, Germany and Italy all close down. Only Spain up on hopes of banking bailout announcement over the weekend
fields.body:
The Dow Jones might be trading up ever so slightly (up 19 points, 0.2%, at 12480) following President Obama's statement on the eurozone, but European markets were less impressed.

The FTSE 100 closed down 13 points, 0.2%, at 5435. The German DAX was also down 19 points, 0.3%, at 6125. So too was France's CAC down 20 points, 0.7%, at 3051 and Italy's FTSE MIB, down 100 points, 0.7%, at 13445.

Rumours of a conference call between Spain and eurozone officials helped the Spanish IBEX 35 rise 114 points, 1.8%, to 6552, but there will probably fall next week without a significant announcement over the weekend.

In London, there was little movement on the largest index throughout the day, with outsourcing firm Capita topping the biggest risers.

The company was up 18p, 2.9%, at 636p on news it had won a 10 year £154m contract with West Sussex county council.

It was followed by Severn Trent, up 47p, 2.7%, at £17.67, after Legal and General increased its stake in the water company from 3% to 4%, buying nearly £4m-worth of extra shares.

BSkyB also put in a good show, closing up 15p, 2.2%, at 681.2p after JP Morgan raised its price target from 790p to 850p – the level shares were trading at before the phone hacking scandal forced the Murdochs to end their pursuit for full control of the company.

For the biggest losers it was as you were, with the miners wiping out the gains made days earlier.

Vedanta down 50p, 5%, at 933.5; Rio Tinto down 146p, 4.8%, at £28.65; Eurasian down 17.4p, 3.9%, at 424.3p.

In the small caps, which closed down just 1 point at 2910, engineering group WSP were the big winners, hitting the 435p target price offered by Canadian rival Genivar, up 67%.

But special mention goes to oil rig maker, Lamprell, which plummeted 24.2p, 22.3%, to 73p after announcing its second profit warning this month. It won't be the end of this saga and suggestions have been made it could get far worse.

Chris Beauchamp, Market Analyst at IG Index summed it up: "Lamprell is the dog of the day, down 20% after announcing its second profit warning in a month. The attempt to sneak the news out yesterday after the market close has not exactly helped matters." Quite.

webTitle: Obama urges Europe to act swiftly to prevent economic collapse

fields.standfirst: President says eurozone crisis remains threat to America's economic recovery as Spain prepares to ask EU for bailout
fields.body:
Europe must act quickly to stem its economic crisis, president Barack Obama said on Friday as he called on European leaders to strengthen their banks and urged Greece to remain in the eurozone.

Obama addressed reporters at the White House as it emerged that Spanish officials would meet EU officials this weekend and ask for help shoring up their troubled banks.

"There is a path out of this challenge. These decisions are in the hands of Europe's leaders; they understand the urgent need to act. There are specific steps they can take right now to prevent the situation from getting worse. One of those steps is taking clear action as soon as possible to inject capital into weak banks," said Obama.

The president said he had been in "constant contact" with European leaders and his own financial advisers as the crisis developed. He urged Greece to act to stay within the eurozone before elections next week arguing that "hardships will likely be worse" if it leaves.

Obama said the US was strong enough to absorb "some of the shocks from across the Atlantic" but that the European crisis was still a threat to America's fragile recovery.

"If Europe goes into recession, that means we are selling fewer goods, fewer services – and that's going to have some impact," he said.

The president also blamed political gridlock for the slow pace of the US recovery. He said Congress's refusal to pass job creation legislation had cost the US economy 1m jobs, and said cuts to government jobs at the local level were holding back the recovery. Obama said the private sector was "doing fine".

His comments were attacked Republican majority leader Eric Cantor. "My question to the president would be: 'are you kidding?'" Cantor said during a press conference.

"Did he see the job numbers that came out last week? The private sector is not doing fine. And, frankly, I'd ask the president to stop engaging in the blame game. It's not because of the headwinds of Europe. It's not because of House Republicans. It's because of the failed stimulus policies and other items in his agenda that small businesses in this country just aren't growing," Cantor added.

The president has begun attacking Republican-backed austerity measures as part of his 2012 election campaign – and has pointed to the failure of austerity to solve the crisis in Europe. "There's nothing fiscally responsible about waiting to fix your roof until it caves in," he said.

"The government of Spain has realised the seriousness of their problem," a senior German official told Reuters.

He added that an agreement had to be reached before a Greek general election on 17 June. If parties opposed to the terms of a European Union-International Monetary Fund bailout win, it could cause market panic and lead to Athens leaving the eurozone.

Spain's banks lent heavily to the construction sector during the property bubble in the first half of the last decade and are now being doubly squeezed because they hold large quantities of Spanish government bonds.

The Fitch downgrade led to a sharp sell-off in European share prices on Friday morning but the reports of a weekend Spanish bank deal reduced the losses.

fields.standfirst: Markets expect reduced demand for fuel from the US and China, and data shows that inflation is easing
fields.body:
Oil prices are heading for their longest losing streak in more than a decade, and there is further good news for squeezed British households as data suggests inflation is easing.

Crude oil prices in New York look to have fallen for six weeks in a row, the longest period of losses since December 1998. Oil has lost 16% this year and touched a low of $82 a barrel before recovering to $82.87, down 2.3%, in New York on Friday. Brent crude in London dropped 2% to $97.96 a barrel, after falling below $97. A month ago Brent was trading at $113.

It comes as figures from the Office for National Statistics on Friday showed a 0.2% drop in the prices charged by manufacturers between April and May, which reduced the annual rate of growth to the lowest since November 2009. Manufacturers' raw material and other costs edged up 0.1% in the year to May, the smallest increase since September 2009, reflecting lower oil costs.

The data bolstered hopes that weaker producer prices would feed into UK consumer prices, which rose 3% in April on the year before, down from a peak of 5.2% in September. This would bring relief to hard-pressed households who have seen real - inflation-adjusted - incomes fall in recent years. However, economists warned that it would take time to have an effect and said that the fall in factory gate inflation over the last six months would not help bring down consumer price inflation until the middle of next year.

Samuel Tombs, UK economist at Capital Economics, said: "Price pressures at the start of the inflation pipeline have begun to fade again, strengthening the case for thinking that consumer price inflation is on course to fall eventually to a very low rate."

Inflation would fall to just 1% by next summer, he said, half the Bank of England's 2% target, and stay there for a couple of years. We could even get deflation if the eurozone breaks up, plunging Britain into a deep recession, he added.

However, a Bank-backed survey carried out last month found that people expected inflation to rise to 3.7% over the coming year, up from forecasts of 3.5% in the previous quarter.

The producer price figures will be welcomed by the Bank, which is thought to be considering pumping more money into the economy through its quantitative easing (QE) programme. It sat on its hand yesterday, despite some forecasts of a £50bn expansion of QE.

"The UK is in recession, inflation is falling and business surveys have softened so the case for further stimulus can be made," said ING economist James Knightley. "However, sterling has weakened on a trade weighted basis over the past month, oil prices are down and 10-year gilt yields are 50 basis points lower. This has given the UK economy a bit more support so it was probable that the BoE felt that it made sense to hold fire until after the Greek elections and deal with any fall out from that."

Markets expect reduced demand for oil from the US and China, the world's biggest consumers of crude, as their economies slow. China cut interest rates on Thursday for the first time since the financial crisis began in 2008, sparking concerns that key economic figures due this weekend could be weak.

In Europe, demand for petrol, diesel and jet fuel has fallen sharply. According to the International Energy Agency, European demand for oil products totalled 13.7m barrels a day in March, down 4.5% on the same month last year. However, motorists in the eurozone have not benefited from lower crude prices as the slide in the euro against the dollar has kept prices at the pump near record highs.

Analysts at Bank of America Merrill Lynch have lowered their 2012 prediction for oil demand in Europe, which they now see falling by nearly 240,000 barrels a day, compared with their previous estimate of 180,000 barrels.

"Highly indebted deficit nations in the eurozone are burning oil and gas they cannot afford," they said. They reckon that said if Greece left the euro, oil demand could slump by a third.

Olivier Jakob, an oil analyst at Petromatrix, said the dropoff in demand would continue. "Everyone is trying to prepare for the exit of Greece," he said. "Economic activity will slow down more and that will have an impact on diesel. I don't see the trend changing, especially in the south."

webTitle: Dow Jones follows Europe's lead, opening down

fields.standfirst:
President Obama set to make a statement on the economy but markets unlikely to rally
Spain's IBEX the only riser on rumours of a bailout this weekend
fields.body:
The Dow Jones Industrial Average opened down today, in line with the rest of Europe.

It is down 28 points, 0.2%, at 12432, but President Obama is making a statement at 10:15am EST (3.15pm BST) about the eurozone crisis and state of the US economy, which has suffered from poor recovery figures of late.

However, if his speech is anything like the lacklustre performance by Federal Reserve chief Ben Bernanke, don't expect fireworks that will set the markets alight.

Strangely, the only major market enjoying any growth today is Spain's IBEX 35 Index on the rumours of a conference call with EU leaders to ask for a bank bailout.

Despite the country's deputy prime minister denying any such call has been set up, some in the market don't believe him, helping the index rise 80 points, 1.3%, to 6517.

Meanwhile, company news from across the Atlantic is few and far between, but the world's biggest hamburger seller, McDonald's has reported lower-than-expected sales rises in May, and warned austerity measures across Europe were taking their toll.

Globally, sales were up 3.3% like-for-like, rising just 2.9% in Europe, but 4.4% in its hungry homeland, the US.

Shares in the Nasdaq-listed company were down $1.65, 1.9%, at $86.73.

fields.standfirst: British businessman Michael Woodford was sacked by Japanese company after he blew whistle on £1bn fraud
fields.body:
Michael Woodford, the British businessman who was sacked as chief executive of Olympus after blowing the whistle on a £1bn fraud scandal, will receive a £10m payoff.

Woodford, who departed two weeks after taking the job, agreed an out-of-court settlement with the Japanese consumer and medical camera maker company last week, which was subject to ratification by the board.

"In today's settlement between myself and the company we reached a fair and amicable agreement, and I would like to take this opportunity to wish the new board well in taking Olympus forward," Woodford said. "It is a wonderful company with wonderful products and people and has a bright future ahead of it."

Last October Woodford, 51, was ordered to return his company mobile and laptop and told to take a bus to the airport after raising the issue of dubious accounting practices with the board. Over the following weeks, regulators uncovered an accounting fraud scandal stretching back more than a decade.

Olympus's shares collapsed by more than 80% in the wake of the scandal and are still trading at half the pre-scandal level. Woodford had demanded 10 years' salary – or $56m (£36.3m) – for wrongful dismissal.

Olympus also said on Friday that it was cutting 2,700 jobs, or 7% of its global workforce, by the end of March 2014 as part of cost-cutting efforts. It will scrap about 40% of its 30 manufacturing plants around the world by the end of March 2015. The company lost ¥49bn (£400m) last year.

webTitle: M&S lose 0.5% of all-important womenswear market, annual report reveals

fields.standfirst: Analysts at Investec warn retailer's share price could fall 8% unless problems are addressed
fields.body:
As Twitter goes into meltdown over who can come up with the least cringeworthy pun on the new Marks and Spencer Bank proposals (this is not just any old bank, etc), analysts at Investec said they believe the share price could drop by 8% after picking through the freshly published annual report.

Their biggest concern is the news that M&S's share of the womenswear market fell 0.5% last year, which is worrying for the country's largest clothing retailer with womenswear its biggest moneymaker.

The note says: "Although the share gain in menswear is a good development, the decline in womenswear is more significant in our view.

"Women are typically the main household shoppers and thus womenswear share movements can be leading indicators.

"We would be less concerned if the recent prelims meeting had discussed womenswear and steps being taken to address the decline – but it was barely mentioned.

"We continue to think that M&S has a number of company-specific issues, including the womens' offer."

Last month the company revealed a fall in underlying pretax profits for the first time in three years.

Chief executive Marc Bolland was forced to abandon his ambitious growth plans to increase sales by between £1.5bn and £2.5bn over three years, revising them down to between £1.1bn and £1.7bn by 2014.

Yesterday's annual report revealed Bolland will receive an annual bonus worth £663,000 made up of £332,000 cash – down 19% on last year – with the remaining in shares which he cannot sell until 2015.

Shares in M&S are down 3.9p, 1.2%, at 336.6p.

webTitle: Eurozone crisis: Spain to seek financial bailout on Saturday

fields.standfirst: Madrid expected to bow to mounting pressure and become fourth eurozone economy to seek help for its debt crisis
fields.body:
Spain is on Saturday expected to become the fourth eurozone country to seek international help for its debt crisis when Europe's policy leaders agree a package to bail out its crippled banking sector.

In the latest attempt to control the financial storm that has threatened the existence of monetary union, sources in Brussels and Germany said Madrid had bowed to mounting pressure and asked for assistance.

A conference call between the 17 members of the eurozone will be held on Saturday – when the financial markets are closed – to discuss the request from the single currency's fourth biggest economy.

The move came less than 24 hours after the ratings agency Fitch slashed Spain's credit worthiness by three notches to just above junk status and warned that its estimate of the cost of a bank bailout had doubled to €60bn (£49bn).

"The government of Spain has realised the seriousness of their problem," a senior German official told the news agency Reuters.

He added that an agreement had to be reached before a Greek general election on 17 June. If parties opposed to the terms of a European Union-International Monetary Fund bailout win, it could cause market panic and lead to Athens leaving the eurozone.

Spain's banks lent heavily to the construction sector during the property bubble in the first half of the last decade and are now being doubly squeezed because they hold large quantities of Spanish government bonds.

The Fitch downgrade led to a sharp sell-off in European share prices on Friday morning but the reports of a weekend Spanish bank deal reduced the losses. At 11.30am the FTSE 100 was 47 points lower at 5400.

webTitle: FTSE Small Cap bucks the trend of the more senior markets

fields.standfirst:
Helped by engineer firm WSP Group up 66% on £278m takeover bid
But oil rig maker Lamprell issues second profit warning in a month sending shares plummeting
fields.body:
Turning away from the big boy markets for a moment, the FTSE Small Cap index was attempting to buck the trend, dropping just 6 points, 0.2%, to 2905.

It was helped primarily by WSP Group, which leaped 172p, 66%, to 432p after the engineering company received a £278m cash offer from Canadian rival Genivar.

The deal, which has been approved by the WSP board and will be put to shareholders, has pushed shares up to just below the offer price of 435p a share.

It has prompted Peel Hunt move from a sell position to hold, saying it does not expect another bidder to become involved.

The company, which used to be part of the FTSE 250, boasts some of the new World Trade Centre site buildings in New York and London's Shard among the projects it is involved with.

With more than 9,000 employees, the company's pretax profits were £19m on revenues of £717.3m.

WSP Chief Executive and founder Christopher Cole will become chairman of Genivar's board after the deal closes and Genivar CEO Pierre Shoiry will maintain his position.

Meanwhile, oil rig maker Lamprell suffered a self-inflicted fall of 27.2p, 27%, to 81.5p after issuing its second profit warning in three weeks.

The announcement was made, unusually, at the close of the markets on Thursday, rather than first thing this morning, but any hopes of burying the bad news failed as the market showed its displeasure.

The UAE-based company said it will make a half-year loss of between $15m and $20m.

Chairman Jonathan Silver resigned as a result, or "move to the position of deputy chairman" as the company prefers to call it.

In May the company issued its first profit warning, putting full-year profits at around $38.5m, compared with the initial $117m estimates. The warning saw it dumped out of the FTSE 250.

The company has blamed a shortage of equipment worldwide and increased costs to wind farm vessels (although the weather has yet to be used as an excuse).

Perhaps most seriously, two senior managers sold shares worth £1.7m just weeks before the first warning in May.

They can expect the recently muscle-flexing FSA to be keeping a close eye on proceedings, although the company deny any wrongdoing.

webTitle: Markets across Europe fall following Spain's downgrade

fields.standfirst: FTSE wipes out Thursday's gains on opening, with miners and banking hit the hardest
fields.body:
What had started as an upbeat week, with expectations pinned on several hoped-for announcements across the world, quickly turned to disappointment by Friday morning, with markets across Europe all opening down.

Within less than an hour of opening, the FTSE 100, was down 56 points, 1%, at 5391, alongside the German DAX down 1.4%, French CAC down 1.8%, Italian FTSE MIB down 2% and Spanish IBEX down 1.1%.

The gloomy mood has not been helped by a raft of poor figures from the eurozone, in particular the major downgrading by ratings agency Fitch of the Spanish economy to BBB – matching it with Mexico and Thailand.

German imports are also down, France's trade deficit widened (although budget deficit narrowed) and the message from the US Fed yesterday was, well, muted.

Casting an early eye over the company performances only 15 of the top 100 companies have seen their share price rise, with top performer, Severn Trent, up just 13p, 0.8%, at £17.49.

The biggest fallers in the top tier are littered with the miners and banks, wiping out any rises in the last few days on the back of excitement that a eurozone solution could be reached, the possibility of my QE and China reducing its interest rates.

fields.bodyText: What had started as an upbeat week, with expectations pinned on several hoped-for announcements across the world, quickly turned to disappointment by Friday morning, with markets across Europe all opening down. Within less than an hour of opening, the FTSE 100, was down 56 points, 1%, at 5391, alongside the German DAX down 1.4%, French CAC down 1.8%, Italian FTSE MIB down 2% and Spanish IBEX down 1.1%. The gloomy mood has not been helped by a raft of poor figures from the eurozone, in particular the major downgrading by ratings agency Fitch of the Spanish economy to BBB – matching it with Mexico and Thailand. German imports are also down, France's trade deficit widened (although budget deficit narrowed) and the message from the US Fed yesterday was, well, muted. Casting an early eye over the company performances only 15 of the top 100 companies have seen their share price rise, with top performer, Severn Trent, up just 13p, 0.8%, at £17.49. Perhaps the rate drop provided a momentary boost at the thought of more money being available to Chinese businesses, but today it is starting to dawn on investors that perhaps the Chinese decision might be because growth in the Far East is about to take a turn for the worse. Either way, Vedanta is down 52p, 5.3%, at 934.3p, Rio Tinto down 133.5p, 4.4%, at £28.81, Royal Bank of Scotland down 8.9p, 4%, at 215.5p and Eurasian down 17.4p, 3.9%, 424.6p.
